Comment: It's adding extra layers to voting, layers which cost money and complicate the process through requiring ever-increasing amounts of documentation.  When I started voting, I presented my driver's license to get my voter registration card, and presented my voter registration card when I voted.  That was it.  With this legislation, I have to have a driver's license, a copy of my birth certificate (which i already had to present in order to get my driver's license) **and** my passport (which i already had to present the previous two identifying documents to acquire), and they all have to match.  If I married and changed my surname to that of my spouse, I have to get a copy of my marriage license in addition to everything else and go through a lengthy process of updating *all of my documentation* before I can vote.  If I've been adopted by a step-parent and taken that person's surname, same thing applies.  It's a big deal because a hundred million people could be disallowed the right to vote, based purely on *manufactured technicalities specifically designed to prevent voters from voting*.  It's called voter suppression.  And it *sucks*.  It's wrong in every way and on every level, an underhanded way for corrupt politicians to secure their offices by pretending that people simply don't exist.  It violates both the spirit of the Constitution and the letter of the law, but, like gerrymandering, it's a tactic that hasn't been ruled illegal (yet).
